awd_titl_txt: The Inclusive Engineering Consortium Stakeholders' Workshop
awd_abstract_narration:
The Inclusive Engineering Consortium (IEC) is planning a workshop for its stakeholders from Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs) and Hispanic Serving Institutions (HSIs) to be held at the Oregon Intel Campus in July 2019. IEC represents a collection of 20+ Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE) programs whose overall vision is to be a collaboration of Minority Serving Institutions (MSIs) Working as One to Advance the ECE Enterprise. It is organized as a virtual super department with broadly based strengths in education, scholarship and service. Collectively, IEC can function as the equal of any ECE program, accomplish more and have a greater impact on its students, faculty and staff through access to resources and opportunities not available individually. It is the earliest of days for IEC and essential that all stakeholders fully participate in creating the organizational support structure and initial activities necessary to realize IEC's grand vision. This workshop will begin IEC's efforts to more fully engage MSIs in the US education and research enterprise; graduate more and better prepared minority engineers; increase efficiency and productivity at MSIs; and develop a sustainable and effective infrastructure to support minority students, faculty and staff at all universities. In time, the IEC group will grow and the model being developed can be replicated and implemented for other disciplines.

Over the last 6 years, a collaboration of 13 HBCU ECE programs has been working together to implement Experiment Centric Pedagogy (ECP) to improve the student learning experience at all partner institutions. The lessons learned and best practices of this effort encouraged the 13 partners to expand the scope of their collaboration to address the full learning and working experience of students, faculty and staff and to expand the group to include other minority serving institutions with ECE and similar programs. Recently, the group has expanded to include two additional HBCUs and two HSIs and is in discussions to add several more. Key to the success of this collaboration is the development of a solid virtual working community of practice through regular meetings including weekly video conferencing and workshops usually held at one of the partner institutions; online resource sharing, and highly collaborative publication/dissemination of results, notably at ASEE conferences. While the original 13 partners continue to solidify and sustain the impact of ECP on improving the learning experiences of their students and the newly augmented group is developing new technical research collaborations, a leadership working group is exploring how to realize the most effective working infrastructure for the evolving consortium. By identifying the primary barriers to future success, it has become clear that a new support organization is necessary if MSI collaborations, like ECP, are to work together as one. With the assistance of the Electrical and Computer Engineering Department Heads Association (ECEDHA), the group has created a new Inclusive Engineering Consortium, consisting of a core group of collaborators and a much larger group of affiliated members from other universities, industry and professional societies. The first face-to-face meeting of the IEC in July 2019 will be organized in coordination with the Intel (IEC's first founding partner) HBCU Consortium Meeting. Planned sessions include Broad Appeal Programs; Investment in Leaders/Future Leaders; Strategic Connections; Infrastructure; and Building IEC.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Inclusive Engineering Consortium (IEC) is an extension of the effective collaboration of thirteen Historically Black College and University (HBCU) Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE) programs.  These thirteen, Howard University (project lead), Alabama A&M University, Florida A&M University, Hampton University, Jackson State University, Morgan State University, Norfolk State University, North Carolina A&T State University, Prairie View A&M University, Southern University, Tennessee State University, Tuskegee University, and University of Maryland Eastern Shore, worked together to implement “Experiment Centric Pedagogy (ECP)” (NSF Award #1255441), to improve the student learning experience.  The lessons learned and best practices of this effort encouraged the partners to expand the scope of their collaboration to address the full experience of students, faculty, and staff and to expand the group to include other minority serving institutions (MSIs).  IEC added Tribal Colleges and Universities (TCUs), Hispanic Serving Institutions (HSIs) and other Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs).  The HBCU programs added were University of the District of Columbia and Virginia State University.  The two HSIs were the University of Texas at El Paso and Turabo University.  The TCU had not yet been added to IEC at the time of this workshop.  Key to the success of this collaboration has been the development of a virtual community of practice through regular meetings.  This workshop was one such meeting.

This workshop was held to solidify and sustain the impact of the newly formed Inclusive Engineering Consortium, IEC.  The vision is to collaborate as one to create a virtual super department. The creation of such a model for collaboration has significant intellectual merit. This workshop will begin IEC’s efforts to engage MSIs more fully in the US education and research enterprise. This fuller engagement will have broader impacts throughout the MSI community.  We proposed a one and one-half day strategic planning workshop focused on the creation of the IEC.  This meeting was held on July 14-15, 2019, in Tigard, Oregon.

The IEC has developed a broad and very challenging vision of enabling MSIs to collaborate as they solve challenges that require larger critical masses than any one program has.  To realize this vision, this workshop brought together IEC’s stakeholders to determine the first strategic steps of the new organization and to begin to create an overall long-term strategic plan. Specifically, the workshop addressed the following four topics: Broad Appeal Programs; Leadership and Professional Development; Strategic Connections; and Support Infrastructure.

It is challenging for consortium institutions to individually conduct large-scale research. More and more institutions are competing for rapidly diminishing funding opportunities. The participants recommended the creation of a database of the research capabilities of members, develop working groups, and seek mutually beneficial collaborations with R1 partners.

The future of any organization depends on the quality of its leadership and clear pathways to professional success. This workshop session explored ideas for how best to help students, staff, and faculty develop as leaders.  Presenters discussed topics such as mentoring, team building, collaboration, communication, networking, and training opportunities. Because of the central nature of their position and impact on the broader organization, the participants decided that the initial focus should be on developing faculty leaders.  Some of these will directly support IEC while others will have an indirect benefit on the IEC membership from their leadership positions.

It is challenging for small to mid-sized programs to establish mutually beneficial relationships with programs at larger research-intensive universities. In a similar way, interactions with government and industry are often focused only on hiring. The goal for this session is to develop an understanding of the elements of mutually beneficial strategic partnerships.  This topic remains challenging.  The participants recommended the inclusion of R1 and government representatives in IEC.  The importance of mutual benefit for all programs was stressed.

The goal for this session was to answer a critical question: What infrastructure is necessary to position IEC for future success? Topics such as the IEC website, web-based support structure, and meeting organization support were addressed.  The partnership with a professional organization management firm has been vital.  Several suggested that IEC establish itself as the lead organization for multi-program funded projects.

In addition to the four focused topics above, a SWOT-style brainstorming session was held. Some of the ideas this session generated include, the importance of a strategic plan, managed growth of the consortium, continued participation of all members, and the importance of a funded effort around which the members could collaborate.

To enhance our degree programs and to improve the overall learning and working experience for all, we are advancing the creation of a virtual department that consists of the entire IEC membership’s faculty.  We further believe that this consortium will allow its members to be more competitive in larger, multi-campus research funding opportunities. Results and insights from IEC and its predecessor group ECP have been published.
